lesson_title: Simple Present Tense: Talking About Your Daily Life
objectives: Understand when to use the Simple Present Tense for habits, facts, and daily routines.
Learn how to make positive, negative, and question sentences in the Simple Present Tense.
Practice using the Simple Present Tense to describe everyday activities and things around you.

sections.text: The Simple Present Tense helps us talk about things we do every day, things that are true all the time, or things that happen regularly. Think of your daily routine, like waking up, eating, or going to school. We use this tense to describe such actions and facts.

examples.label: I wake up early.
examples.value: This is something you do every morning. It's a habit.

examples.label: The sun rises in the east.
examples.value: This is a fact that is always true. [7]

examples.label: Birds sing in the morning.
examples.value: This happens regularly. It's a general truth.

examples.label: Our school starts at 9 AM.
examples.value: This is a fixed schedule.

examples.label: My father works in the field.
examples.value: This describes a regular activity or profession.

examples.label: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius.
examples.value: This is a scientific fact. [7]

examples.label: We eat dinner together every night.
examples.value: This is a family habit or routine.

examples.label: The river flows near our village.
examples.value: This is a permanent situation or general truth.

examples.label: Cows give us milk.
examples.value: This is a general fact about cows.

examples.label: My mother prays every day.
examples.value: This is a regular habit or routine.

examples.label: The earth revolves around the sun.
examples.value: This is a universal fact. [7]

examples.label: Children love playing games.
examples.value: This is a general truth about children's preferences.

usage_examples: I go to the market every Sunday.
She milks the cow in the morning.
We grow wheat in our farm.
They study in the village school.

sections.text: For 'I', 'You', 'We', and 'They', we use the simple form of the verb. This means we don't add anything to the verb.

examples.label: I eat.
examples.value: The verb is 'eat'. We use it as it is.

examples.label: You play.
examples.value: The verb is 'play'. No change.

examples.label: We learn.
examples.value: The verb is 'learn'. No change.

examples.label: They work.
examples.value: The verb is 'work'. No change.

examples.label: I read books every night.
examples.value: The verb 'read' remains unchanged for 'I'.

examples.label: You sing very well.
examples.value: The verb 'sing' remains unchanged for 'You'.

examples.label: We help each other in the village.
examples.value: The verb 'help' remains unchanged for 'We'.

examples.label: They visit their grandparents often.
examples.value: The verb 'visit' remains unchanged for 'They'.

examples.label: I grow vegetables in my garden.
examples.value: The verb 'grow' is used in its base form.

examples.label: You always speak the truth.
examples.value: The verb 'speak' is used in its base form.

examples.label: We listen to folk songs.
examples.value: The verb 'listen' is used in its base form.

examples.label: They feed the chickens every morning.
examples.value: The verb 'feed' is used in its base form.

examples.label: I enjoy simple food.
examples.value: The verb 'enjoy' is used in its base form.

examples.label: You teach us new things.
examples.value: The verb 'teach' is used in its base form.

usage_examples: I work in the field every day.
We play cricket in the evening.
They live in a big house.
I drink water from the well.

table.title: Positive Sentence Structure: I, You, We, They

sections.text: For 'He', 'She', and 'It' (or a single person/thing), we add '-s' or '-es' to the end of the verb. This is a very important rule to remember.

examples.label: He eats.
examples.value: The verb 'eat' becomes 'eats'.

examples.label: She plays.
examples.value: The verb 'play' becomes 'plays'.

examples.label: It runs.
examples.value: The verb 'run' becomes 'runs'.

examples.label: My brother watches TV.
examples.value: The verb 'watch' becomes 'watches' for 'My brother' (He).

examples.label: The dog barks at strangers.
examples.value: The verb 'bark' becomes 'barks' for 'The dog' (It).

examples.label: She milks the cow in the morning.
examples.value: The verb 'milk' becomes 'milks' for 'She'.

examples.label: He goes to school every day.
examples.value: The verb 'go' becomes 'goes' for 'He'. [5]

examples.label: The farmer grows rice.
examples.value: The verb 'grow' becomes 'grows' for 'The farmer' (He).

examples.label: It rains a lot here in monsoon.
examples.value: The verb 'rain' becomes 'rains' for 'It'.

examples.label: My sister sings beautifully.
examples.value: The verb 'sing' becomes 'sings' for 'My sister' (She).

examples.label: He teaches English.
examples.value: The verb 'teach' becomes 'teaches' for 'He'.

examples.label: The cat sleeps on the mat.
examples.value: The verb 'sleep' becomes 'sleeps' for 'The cat' (It).

table.title: Positive Sentence Structure: He, She, It

sections.text: Sometimes, we add '-es' instead of just '-s'. This happens when the verb ends with certain letters. Let's look at the rules.

examples.label: Verbs ending in -ch, -sh, -x, -s, -ss, -z, -o:
examples.value: Add -es. (e.g., watch -> watches, wash -> washes, fix -> fixes, pass -> passes, buzz -> buzzes, go -> goes) [5]

examples.label: He watches TV.
examples.value: Watch ends in -ch, so we add -es.

examples.label: She washes clothes.
examples.value: Wash ends in -sh, so we add -es.

examples.label: It fixes problems.
examples.value: Fix ends in -x, so we add -es.

examples.label: He passes the ball.
examples.value: Pass ends in -ss, so we add -es.

examples.label: She goes to the temple.
examples.value: Go ends in -o, so we add -es. [5]

examples.label: Verbs ending in consonant + -y:
examples.value: Change -y to -i and add -es. (e.g., study -> studies, cry -> cries, carry -> carries) [5]

examples.label: She studies English.
examples.value: Study ends in -dy (consonant + y), so it becomes studies.

examples.label: The baby cries loudly.
examples.value: Cry ends in -ry (consonant + y), so it becomes cries.

examples.label: He carries a bag.
examples.value: Carry ends in -ry (consonant + y), so it becomes carries.

examples.label: Verbs ending in vowel + -y:
examples.value: Just add -s. (e.g., play -> plays, enjoy -> enjoys, buy -> buys)

examples.label: He plays football.
examples.value: Play ends in -ay (vowel + y), so we just add -s.

examples.label: She enjoys music.
examples.value: Enjoy ends in -oy (vowel + y), so we just add -s.

usage_examples: The bird flies over the fields.
He buys vegetables from the market.
It often buzzes near the light.

table.title: Spelling Rules for -s / -es Endings
rows: teach -> teaches, wash -> washes, fix -> fixes, pass -> passes, go -> goes

sections.text: To make a negative sentence for 'I', 'You', 'We', and 'They', we add 'do not' (or 'don't') before the main verb. The verb remains in its base form.

examples.label: I do not (don't) like coffee.
examples.value: We add 'do not' before 'like'.

examples.label: You do not (don't) live here.
examples.value: We add 'do not' before 'live'.

examples.label: We do not (don't) play games every day.
examples.value: We add 'do not' before 'play'.

examples.label: They do not (don't) go to school on Sunday.
examples.value: We add 'do not' before 'go'.

examples.label: I don't eat meat.
examples.value: Contraction 'don't' is used.

examples.label: You don't understand the problem.
examples.value: Contraction 'don't' is used.

examples.label: We don't watch TV in the morning.
examples.value: Contraction 'don't' is used. [3]

examples.label: They don't have a car.
examples.value: Contraction 'don't' is used.

examples.label: I do not work on Fridays.
examples.value: Formal use of 'do not'.

examples.label: You do not like spicy food.
examples.value: Formal use of 'do not'.

examples.label: We do not waste water.
examples.value: Formal use of 'do not'.

examples.label: They do not live in the city.
examples.value: Formal use of 'do not'.

table.title: Negative Sentence Structure: I, You, We, They

sections.text: For 'He', 'She', and 'It', we add 'does not' (or 'doesn't') before the main verb. Remember, the main verb goes back to its base form (no -s or -es) when we use 'does not'.

examples.label: He does not (doesn't) like milk.
examples.value: We add 'does not' before 'like'. 'Like' remains base form.

examples.label: She does not (doesn't) play cricket.
examples.value: We add 'does not' before 'play'. 'Play' remains base form. [3]

examples.label: It does not (doesn't) work.
examples.value: We add 'does not' before 'work'. 'Work' remains base form. [3]

examples.label: My father doesn't smoke.
examples.value: Contraction 'doesn't' is used. 'Smoke' is base form.

examples.label: The cow doesn't eat meat.
examples.value: Contraction 'doesn't' is used. 'Eat' is base form.

examples.label: He does not live in this village anymore.
examples.value: Formal use of 'does not'.

examples.label: She does not speak English very well.
examples.value: Formal use of 'does not'.

examples.label: It does not happen often.
examples.value: Formal use of 'does not'.

examples.label: My sister doesn't like spicy food.
examples.value: Even though it's 'she', 'like' is base form.

examples.label: The well doesn't have much water.
examples.value: Even though it's 'it', 'have' is base form.

examples.label: He doesn't waste electricity.
examples.value: No -s/-es on 'waste' because 'doesn't' is present.

examples.label: She doesn't forget her keys.
examples.value: No -s/-es on 'forget' because 'doesn't' is present.

usage_examples: He doesn't go to the city.
My brother doesn't wake up early.
The dog doesn't bark at night.
He doesn't eat rice every day.

table.title: Negative Sentence Structure: He, She, It

sections.text: To ask a question for 'I', 'You', 'We', and 'They', we put 'Do' at the beginning of the sentence. The verb remains in its base form.

examples.label: Do I need to go?
examples.value: We start with 'Do'. The verb 'need' is base form.

examples.label: Do you understand?
examples.value: We start with 'Do'. The verb 'understand' is base form.

examples.label: Do we have enough food?
examples.value: We start with 'Do'. The verb 'have' is base form.

examples.label: Do they play soccer?
examples.value: We start with 'Do'. The verb 'play' is base form.

examples.label: Do I look tired?
examples.value: Asking about appearance.

examples.label: Do you live in this village?
examples.value: Asking about residence.

examples.label: Do we share the same dream?
examples.value: Asking about shared feelings.

examples.label: Do they always arrive late?
examples.value: Asking about a habit.

examples.label: Do I explain clearly?
examples.value: Asking for feedback.

examples.label: Do you like the local festival?
examples.value: Asking about preference.

examples.label: Do we learn from our mistakes?
examples.value: Asking a general truth question.

examples.label: Do they help in the farm work?
examples.value: Asking about their contribution.

usage_examples: Do we need water for the plants?
Do you go to the river?
Do you eat rice for dinner?

table.title: Question Sentence Structure: I, You, We, They

sections.text: To ask a question for 'He', 'She', and 'It', we put 'Does' at the beginning of the sentence. The main verb goes back to its base form (no -s or -es).

examples.label: Does he like sweet food?
examples.value: We start with 'Does'. 'Like' is base form.

examples.label: Does she enjoy reading?
examples.value: We start with 'Does'. 'Enjoy' is base form.

examples.label: Does it rain much in July?
examples.value: We start with 'Does'. 'Rain' is base form.

examples.label: Does your brother play the flute?
examples.value: Asking about 'your brother' (He).

examples.label: Does the bus leave at 6 AM?
examples.value: Asking about 'the bus' (It).

examples.label: Does he work hard?
examples.value: Asking about his work ethic.

examples.label: Does she visit her village often?
examples.value: Asking about her habits.

examples.label: Does it smell fresh?
examples.value: Asking about a quality.

examples.label: Does the river flow fast?
examples.value: Asking about the river's condition.

examples.label: Does he help his mother with chores?
examples.value: Asking about his daily routine.

examples.label: Does she always tell the truth?
examples.value: Asking about her character/habit.

examples.label: Does this road go to the city?
examples.value: Asking for directions about 'this road' (It).

usage_examples: Does the dog bark at night?
Does the farmer sell his crops?

table.title: Question Sentence Structure: He, She, It

topics.title: When to Use Simple Present Tense

sections.text: We use the Simple Present Tense to talk about things we do regularly, every day, or often. These are our habits and routines.

examples.label: I wake up at 6 AM every day.
examples.value: This is a daily routine. [7]

examples.label: She goes to the market on Mondays.
examples.value: This is a regular activity. [5]

examples.label: We drink tea in the morning.
examples.value: This is a daily habit. [7]

examples.label: He brushes his teeth twice a day.
examples.value: This is a daily habit.

examples.label: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
examples.value: This is a regular habit.

examples.label: Birds build nests in spring.
examples.value: This is a repeated action that happens every year.

examples.label: The children play outside after school.
examples.value: This is a regular activity for the children.

examples.label: My mother cooks fresh food every day.
examples.value: This is a daily routine.

examples.label: We celebrate Diwali every year.
examples.value: This is a recurring event or tradition.

examples.label: He visits his grandparents every weekend.
examples.value: This is a regular routine.

examples.label: I study English for one hour daily.
examples.value: This is a daily routine.

examples.label: She practices singing in the evening.
examples.value: This is a regular habit.

usage_examples: The bus leaves at 8 o'clock every morning.
You usually come home by dusk.
We watch the sunset from the hill.

sections.text: We use the Simple Present Tense to talk about things that are always true, scientific facts, or general truths about the world.

examples.label: The sun rises in the east.
examples.value: This is a universal truth. [7]

examples.label: Water freezes at zero degrees Celsius.
examples.value: This is a scientific fact. [7]

examples.label: The Earth revolves around the Sun.
examples.value: This is a scientific fact. [7]

examples.label: Fish live in water.
examples.value: This is a general truth about fish.

examples.label: Honey is sweet.
examples.value: This is a general quality or fact.

examples.label: Doctors help sick people.
examples.value: This is a general truth about their profession.

examples.label: Our village has a big pond.
examples.value: This states a permanent fact about the village.

examples.label: Cows eat grass.
examples.value: This is a general truth about cows.

examples.label: Birds fly in the sky.
examples.value: This is a general truth about birds.

examples.label: Trees give us oxygen.
examples.value: This is a general truth about trees.

examples.label: The moon shines at night.
examples.value: This is a general fact.

examples.label: Fire is hot.
examples.value: This is a basic fact.

usage_examples: The river flows to the sea.

sections.text: Sometimes, we use the Simple Present Tense to talk about future events that are fixed or scheduled, like a timetable or a calendar event.

examples.label: The train departs at 5 PM.
examples.value: This is a fixed timetable. [7]

examples.label: Our holiday starts next week.
examples.value: This is a fixed arrangement.

examples.label: The school reopens in June.
examples.value: This is a fixed schedule.

examples.label: The movie starts at 7 o'clock tonight.
examples.value: This is a fixed schedule for a future event.

examples.label: The festival begins on Friday.
examples.value: This is a scheduled event.

examples.label: My exams end next month.
examples.value: This is a fixed date for a future event.

examples.label: The meeting finishes at 3 PM.
examples.value: This is a scheduled ending time.

examples.label: His flight arrives at 10 AM tomorrow.
examples.value: This is a fixed travel schedule. [13]

examples.label: The market closes at 9 PM.
examples.value: This is a regular closing time, but can refer to a specific future instance.

examples.label: The bus comes in 10 minutes.
examples.value: This is a near future scheduled arrival.

usage_examples: The new bridge opens next year.
The doctor's clinic closes early today.
The fair starts on the first of April.
Our school trip is next month.
The post office opens at 9 AM.

sections.text: We also use the Simple Present Tense to give instructions or directions, telling someone how to do something or where to go.

examples.label: First, you open the book.
examples.value: This is the first step in an instruction.

examples.label: Then, you read the first chapter.
examples.value: This is the next step in an instruction.

examples.label: You turn left at the crossroads.
examples.value: This is a direction.

examples.label: You add water to the mixture.
examples.value: This is a step in a recipe or instruction.

examples.label: You press this button to start.
examples.value: This is a clear instruction.

examples.label: You walk straight for five minutes.
examples.value: This is a direction.

examples.label: First, you grind the spices.
examples.value: Step in cooking.

examples.label: Then, you add them to the pot.
examples.value: Next step in cooking.

examples.label: You cross the bridge.
examples.value: Direction.

examples.label: You mix the flour with water.
examples.value: Instruction for preparing dough.

usage_examples: You give the book to him.
You put the seeds in the soil.

topics.title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them (Simple Present)

sections.text: A very common mistake is forgetting to add '-s' or '-es' to the verb when the subject is 'He', 'She', 'It', or a singular noun. Always remember this rule!

examples.label: Incorrect: She go to school.
examples.value: Correct: She goes to school. ('She' needs -es with 'go')

examples.label: Incorrect: He like mangoes.
examples.value: Correct: He likes mangoes. ('He' needs -s with 'like')

examples.label: Incorrect: The cat sleep on the bed.
examples.value: Correct: The cat sleeps on the bed. ('The cat' (It) needs -s with 'sleep')

examples.label: Incorrect: My brother play football.
examples.value: Correct: My brother plays football. ('My brother' (He) needs -s with 'play')

examples.label: Incorrect: It rain a lot in July.
examples.value: Correct: It rains a lot in July. ('It' needs -s with 'rain')

examples.label: Incorrect: She watch TV every evening.
examples.value: Correct: She watches TV every evening. ('She' needs -es with 'watch')

examples.label: Incorrect: He study English.
examples.value: Correct: He studies English. ('He' needs -ies with 'study')

examples.label: Incorrect: The shop open at 9 AM.
examples.value: Correct: The shop opens at 9 AM. ('The shop' (It) needs -s with 'open')

examples.label: Incorrect: He help his father.
examples.value: Correct: He helps his father. ('He' needs -s with 'help')

examples.label: Incorrect: My sister read books.
examples.value: Correct: My sister reads books. ('My sister' (She) needs -s with 'read')

examples.label: Incorrect: The dog bark loudly.
examples.value: Correct: The dog barks loudly. ('The dog' (It) needs -s with 'bark')

usage_examples: Incorrect: She eat rice. -> Correct: She eats rice.
Incorrect: He like sweets. -> Correct: He likes sweets.
Incorrect: It seem good. -> Correct: It seems good.
Incorrect: The boy cry. -> Correct: The boy cries.
Incorrect: My friend live here. -> Correct: My friend lives here.
Incorrect: He watch news. -> Correct: He watches news.
Incorrect: She do homework. -> Correct: She does homework.
Incorrect: The baby sleep. -> Correct: The baby sleeps.
Incorrect: He always come late. -> Correct: He always comes late.
Incorrect: The teacher explain well. -> Correct: The teacher explains well.

subtopics.title: Mistake 2: Incorrect Use of 'do/does' in Negatives/Questions

sections.text: Another common mistake is using 'do/does' incorrectly or forgetting to use the base form of the verb after 'do/does' in negative and question sentences. Remember, 'do' and 'does' already carry the tense.

examples.label: Incorrect: She doesn't likes tea.
examples.value: Correct: She doesn't like tea. (After 'doesn't', use base verb 'like')

examples.label: Incorrect: He don't play football.
examples.value: Correct: He doesn't play football. ('He' needs 'doesn't', not 'don't')

examples.label: Incorrect: Do he go to school?
examples.value: Correct: Does he go to school? ('He' needs 'Does', not 'Do')

examples.label: Incorrect: You doesn't understand.
examples.value: Correct: You don't understand. ('You' needs 'don't', not 'doesn't')

examples.label: Incorrect: Does she eats rice?
examples.value: Correct: Does she eat rice? (After 'Does', use base verb 'eat')

examples.label: Incorrect: I doesn't like this.
examples.value: Correct: I don't like this. ('I' needs 'don't', not 'doesn't')

examples.label: Incorrect: They doesn't live here.
examples.value: Correct: They don't live here. ('They' needs 'don't', not 'doesn't')

examples.label: Incorrect: Does it works well?
examples.value: Correct: Does it work well? (After 'Does', use base verb 'work')

examples.label: Incorrect: We doesn't know him.
examples.value: Correct: We don't know him. ('We' needs 'don't', not 'doesn't')

examples.label: Incorrect: Do she come?
examples.value: Correct: Does she come? ('She' needs 'Does')

examples.label: Incorrect: He not play.
examples.value: Correct: He doesn't play. (Needs 'does not')

examples.label: Incorrect: I not understand.
examples.value: Correct: I don't understand. (Needs 'do not')

usage_examples: Incorrect: She doesn't studies. -> Correct: She doesn't study.
Incorrect: Do you likes it? -> Correct: Do you like it?
Incorrect: He not go to market. -> Correct: He doesn't go to market.
Incorrect: Does the sun rises in the west? -> Correct: Does the sun rise in the west?
Incorrect: They doesn't have water. -> Correct: They don't have water.
Incorrect: Does it rains much? -> Correct: Does it rain much?
Incorrect: We not want food. -> Correct: We don't want food.
Incorrect: Does your brother plays? -> Correct: Does your brother play?
Incorrect: The child doesn't cries. -> Correct: The child doesn't cry.
Incorrect: Do I eats too much? -> Correct: Do I eat too much?

sections.text: The Present Continuous tense (also called Present Progressive) is used to talk about actions that are happening right now, at the moment of speaking. It can also describe temporary situations or planned future events. [3, 5, 8, 11, 19, 21, 23]

examples.label: I am teaching a class.
examples.value: This action is happening right now.

examples.label: The children are playing outside.
examples.value: This describes an activity in progress at this moment. [31]

examples.label: She is staying with her grandmother for a week.
examples.value: This is a temporary situation, not a permanent one. [8, 31]

examples.label: It is raining.
examples.value: This is happening at the present moment. [8, 32]

examples.label: We are meeting our friends tomorrow.
examples.value: This is a planned event in the future. [8, 11, 21]

usage_examples: I am writing a letter now.
He is working on a new project these days.
They are building a new house.

sections.text: To form the Present Continuous tense, we use the present form of the verb 'to be' (am, is, are) followed by the main verb with an '-ing' ending. [21, 32, 37, 38]

examples.label: Positive: I am eating.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + am + verb-ing. [21]

examples.label: Positive: He is cooking. / She is reading.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + is + verb-ing. [21, 31]

examples.label: Positive: They are playing. / We are learning.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + are + verb-ing. [21]

examples.label: Negative: I am not sleeping.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + am + not + verb-ing. [18, 21]

examples.label: Negative: He isn't working.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + is + not (isn't) + verb-ing. [21]

examples.label: Negative: They aren't going.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + are + not (aren't) + verb-ing. [8]

examples.label: Question: Am I dreaming?
examples.value: Structure: Am + subject + verb-ing? [21]

examples.label: Question: Is she crying?
examples.value: Structure: Is + subject + verb-ing? [21]

examples.label: Question: Are you listening?
examples.value: Structure: Are + subject + verb-ing? [20]

usage_examples: The farmer is plowing the field.
They are not making any noise.

sections.text: Common errors include forgetting the 'to be' verb (am, is, are) or using this tense with verbs that describe states, not actions (stative verbs). [16, 18, 20, 28, 34]

examples.label: Incorrect: He reading a book.
examples.value: Correct: He is reading a book. (Missing 'is'). [34]

examples.label: Incorrect: I am knowing the answer.
examples.value: Correct: I know the answer. ('Know' is a stative verb and not typically used in the continuous form). [18, 28, 38]

examples.label: Incorrect: They is playing.
examples.value: Correct: They are playing. (Incorrect subject-verb agreement). [18]

examples.label: Incorrect: She not is working.
examples.value: Correct: She is not working. (Incorrect word order for negative sentence).

sections.text: The Present Perfect tense connects the past with the present. It is used for actions that happened at an unspecified time before now, or actions that started in the past and are still true today. The focus is often on the result of the action, not when it happened. [1, 4, 7, 9]

examples.label: I have finished my work.
examples.value: The work is done. The result is that I am free now. The exact time is not mentioned. [4]

examples.label: She has lived here for five years.
examples.value: This action started in the past and continues into the present. She still lives here. [4, 7]

examples.label: They have seen this movie before.
examples.value: This refers to a life experience at an unspecified time in the past. [14]

examples.label: He has just left.
examples.value: This action was completed in the very recent past and is connected to the present moment. [4, 7]

examples.label: We have never been to that village.
examples.value: This describes an experience (or lack of it) up to now.

usage_examples: She has bought a new saree.
Have you ever seen a tiger?
The farmer has sold his crops.
We haven't received any rain this month.

sections.text: To form the Present Perfect tense, we use the auxiliary verb 'have' or 'has' followed by the past participle (the third form) of the main verb. [7, 9, 22, 30]

examples.label: Positive: I have eaten. / You have worked.
examples.value: Structure: Subject (I/You/We/They) + have + past participle.

examples.label: Positive: He has gone. / She has slept.
examples.value: Structure: Subject (He/She/It) + has + past participle.

examples.label: Negative: We have not (haven't) finished.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + have + not + past participle. [7]

examples.label: Negative: He has not (hasn't) arrived yet.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + has + not + past participle. [7, 22]

examples.label: Question: Have you seen him?
examples.value: Structure: Have + subject + past participle?

examples.label: Question: Has she called?
examples.value: Structure: Has + subject + past participle?

usage_examples: My father has gone to the city.
I have already finished my homework.
She has never told a lie.
They haven't built the road yet.

sections.text: Common mistakes include using it with specific past time adverbs (like 'yesterday') or confusing the past participle forms of irregular verbs. [9, 22, 24, 33, 35]

examples.label: Incorrect: I have finished my work yesterday.
examples.value: Correct: I finished my work yesterday. (Use Simple Past for specific past times). [9]

examples.label: Incorrect: She has went to the market.
examples.value: Correct: She has gone to the market. ('Gone' is the past participle of 'go', not 'went'). [35]

examples.label: Incorrect: They have ate all the food.
examples.value: Correct: They have eaten all the food. ('Eaten' is the past participle of 'eat'). [33]

examples.label: Incorrect: He have done his job.
examples.value: Correct: He has done his job. (Use 'has' for he/she/it). [33, 35]

subtopics.title: What is Present Perfect Continuous Tense?

sections.text: The Present Perfect Continuous tense (also Present Perfect Progressive) is used for an action that started in the past and is still continuing now. It often emphasizes the duration of the action. It can also be used for an action that has just finished but has a result we can see now. [2, 6, 10, 12, 13, 25]

examples.label: I have been waiting for two hours.
examples.value: The action of waiting started in the past and is still happening. The duration ('for two hours') is emphasized. [2, 6]

examples.label: She has been working in the garden all morning.
examples.value: This emphasizes the continuous activity over a period of time. [13]

examples.label: It has been raining since last night.
examples.value: The rain started last night and is still continuing. [10, 12]

examples.label: Why are your clothes dirty? - I have been cleaning the house.
examples.value: The action of cleaning recently finished, and the result (dirty clothes) is visible now. [10]

examples.label: They have been living here for a long time.
examples.value: This describes a situation that began in the past and continues to the present. [15]

usage_examples: He has been studying since morning.
We have been building this wall for a month.
How long have you been learning English?
They have been travelling for three days.

subtopics.title: Making Sentences in Present Perfect Continuous

sections.text: To form the Present Perfect Continuous tense, we use 'have/has' + 'been' + the main verb with an '-ing' ending. [2, 6, 13, 17, 29]

examples.label: Positive: I have been reading.
examples.value: Structure: Subject (I/You/We/They) + have + been + verb-ing. [2, 29]

examples.label: Positive: She has been sleeping.
examples.value: Structure: Subject (He/She/It) + has + been + verb-ing. [2, 29]

examples.label: Negative: They have not (haven't) been playing.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + have + not + been + verb-ing. [2, 29]

examples.label: Negative: He has not (hasn't) been feeling well.
examples.value: Structure: Subject + has + not + been + verb-ing. [2, 29]

examples.label: Question: Have you been waiting long?
examples.value: Structure: Have + subject + been + verb-ing? [10, 29]

examples.label: Question: Has it been raining?
examples.value: Structure: Has + subject + been + verb-ing? [2, 10]

usage_examples: The farmers have been working in the fields since dawn.
She hasn't been practicing the sitar lately.
Have they been living in that hut for many years?
My mother has been cooking all day.
I have been trying to call you.

sections.text: Common mistakes include using this tense with stative verbs (like 'know' or 'want') or forgetting the word 'been'. [15, 17, 26, 27]

examples.label: Incorrect: I have been knowing him for a long time.
examples.value: Correct: I have known him for a long time. ('Know' is a stative verb). [15, 27]

examples.label: Incorrect: They have working since morning.
examples.value: Correct: They have been working since morning. (Missing 'been'). [26]

examples.label: Incorrect: She is been studying for three hours.
examples.value: Correct: She has been studying for three hours. (Using 'is' instead of 'has'). [17]

examples.label: Incorrect: I have been living here for 2010.
examples.value: Correct: I have been living here since 2010. (Incorrect use of 'for' instead of 'since' with a point in time). [15, 17]
